san_ignacio_system.systemName: SAN IGNACIO - Coastal Rural Multi-Hazard Resilient Building System
san_ignacio_system.purpose: A comprehensive design and construction framework for resilient buildings in San Ignacio's coastal rural agricultural community, addressing vulnerability to flooding, storm surge, sea level rise, earthquakes, tsunamis, ash fall, and typhoons. This system prioritizes elevated, water-resistant foundations; robust concrete structures with seismic ductility; secure, lightweight metal roofing; and composite or reinforced concrete framing to ensure survival and recovery through multiple natural hazards.
san_ignacio_system.note: This is a conceptual document for general guidance only. Final design, engineering, and construction must comply with applicable building codes, local regulations, and site-specific conditions. Consultation with qualified structural engineers, geotechnical specialists, and coastal engineering experts is essential for proper implementation in San Ignacio's multi-hazard coastal rural environment.
design_approach: Water Resilience: Implement elevated pile or stilt foundations to allow flood and surge water flow-through, combined with pile-supported structures (minimum 1-2 meters above design flood level) to prevent debris accumulation and reduce hydrostatic pressure on buildings.

Seismic Ductility: Use reinforced concrete (RC) shear walls and composite (steel + concrete) beams to provide lateral strength and ductility during ground shaking, preventing brittle failure and allowing plastic deformation before structural collapse.

Typhoon Wind Resistance: Design hip roof structures to reduce uplift forces, secure all roof-to-wall connections with anchors, use corrosion-resistant metal roofing with proper fastening patterns, and ensure columns and beams are properly braced against lateral wind forces.

Tsunami & Surge Survivability: Prioritize column-and-beam structural systems (soft story with strong perimeter walls) over solid walls, allowing water and debris to pass through lower levels while maintaining structural integrity; avoid trapping water that increases hydrodynamic forces.

Ash & Wind Load Handling: Design roof slopes (hip preferred, minimum 20 pitch) to shed ash and water naturally, use lightweight metal roofing to minimize total load during ash accumulation and seismic events, and provide internal drainage systems to prevent ponding and structural overload.

recommended_components.walls: Full reinforced concrete (RC) wall system with RC shear walls as the primary lateral system. Best overall performance against water and debris impact (flood/surge/sea level rise), excellent ductility in earthquakes (with continuous rebar), strong resistance to typhoon wind forces (rigid, heavy, good roof anchorage), and good capability for ash load distribution. Shear walls (solid RC) should be the primary design choice.
recommended_components.foundation_material: Reinforced concrete (RC) foundation. Highly durable in wet and saline coastal exposure; provides ductile response with steel reinforcement during seismic events; strong anchorage capability against typhoon uplift forces; excellent support for accumulated ash loads on upper structure.
recommended_components.foundation_structure: Pile foundation (deep piles, 8-12 meters minimum). Provides deep anchorage to prevent scour and erosion in flood/surge/sea-level-rise events; improves performance in soft coastal soils; limits differential settlement and liquefaction risk during earthquakes; supports elevation for surge and sea level rise protection; allows water and debris flow-through without resistance.
recommended_components.roof_structure: Hip roof geometry. Best all-around design for typhoons (greatly reduces uplift forces), naturally sheds rain and ash accumulation, provides stable geometry during seismic shaking, and minimizes interior leakage at roof-wall intersections compared to gable roofs.
recommended_components.roof_material: Metal roofing (corrugated steel or aluminum, corrosion-resistant coating). Lightweight for earthquake loads; can be securely fastened with appropriate pattern to resist typhoon uplift; excellent water and ash shedding; must use high-quality corrosion-resistant coating or stainless steel for long-term durability in coastal salt-spray environment.
recommended_components.columns: Reinforced concrete (RCC) circular columns, minimum 400mm diameter. Durable and strong for flood, surge, and typhoon forces; excellent seismic performance with proper detailing and confinement; good support for accumulated ash loads; circular cross-section provides better seismic performance than square.
recommended_components.beams: Composite beams (structural steel + reinforced concrete composite action). Best overall balanceprovides ductility in earthquakes, strong resistance to typhoon and tsunami impact forces, excellent capacity for heavy ash loads; requires proper corrosion protection of steel components in coastal environment (paint, epoxy, or stainless).
recommended_components.floors: Steel-reinforced concrete floor slabs (solid or composite). Water-resistant and non-combustible; strong capacity for accumulated ash loads; provides good diaphragm action for seismic load distribution; resists typhoon uplift forces when properly anchored to supporting beams and columns.
recommended_components.interior_partitions: Fiber cement or gypsum board non-structural partitions over RC frame. Lightweight to reduce seismic mass; allows interior flexibility for post-disaster adaptation; provides some fire and water resistance; non-load-bearing design simplifies repairs.
recommended_components.door_and_window_design: Aluminum or PVC frames with tempered or laminated glass; sliding doors with secure latches or storm shutters. Reduces wind-borne debris impact hazard; secure fastening to RC frame prevents blow-out during typhoons; tempered glass reduces sharp fragments; operable shutters allow occupants to reduce openings during storm.

alternative_components.walls_tertiary: Fiber cement board for non-structural interior and upper walls: Lightweight option; must be properly framed with RC or steel backing; lower impact resistance than concrete in flood/debris events. Trade-off: Cost savings, but requires careful detailing and cannot carry lateral loads.
alternative_components.foundation_material_alt: Precast concrete pile and cap system: Good quality control in manufacturing; potential weakness at joints and assembly if not executed to high standards; seismic reliability depends on connection detailing. Trade-off: Faster installation, but higher sensitivity to workmanship.
alternative_components.foundation_structure_alt1: Raft or mat foundation: Excellent for distributing earthquake loads and accommodating uneven soil settlement; must be combined with elevation platform and good drainage system for flood safety; requires thicker concrete for structural depth. Trade-off: Simpler for soft soils, but needs elevation and drainage features for coastal applicability.
alternative_components.foundation_structure_alt2: Stilt or pier foundation (elevated post-and-beam): Excellent for elevation in flood/surge/sea-level-rise/tsunami flow-through environments; needs strong diagonal bracing for earthquake and wind forces; avoid vulnerable materials like unprotected wood. Trade-off: High elevation and flow-through, but requires robust lateral bracing.
alternative_components.roof_structure_alt: Gable or gable-hip roof: Can work in multi-hazard context but needs extra diagonal bracing and careful detailing at roof-wall intersections; more vulnerable to typhoon wind uplift at ridge and eaves. alternative_components.roof_material_alt1: Concrete slab roof (solid concrete deck): Excellent resistance to wind and water penetration; provides fireproofing and ash load capacity; too heavy unless entire structure is engineered for seismic loads; higher cost and needs excellent waterproofing membrane. alternative_components.floors_alt: Hollow core or composite floor slabs: Lighter than solid concrete; reduces overall structural weight for earthquakes; still provides good water and ash resistance; limits clear span and creates more joints. Trade-off: Weight reduction, but more complex detailing.
